column2: My father, at the death of his father, was but six years of age; and he grew up, literally without education.
column3: My father, at the death of his father, was but six years of age; and he grew up, literally without education.

column2: CHAPTER II
column3: CHAPTER two

column2: ABRAHAM LINCOLN'S FATHER AND MOTHER
column3: ABRAHAM LINCOLN'S FATHER AND MOTHER

column2: While Thomas Lincoln was living with a farmer and doing odd jobs of carpentering, he met Nancy Hanks, a tall, slender woman, with dark skin, dark brown hair and small, deep-set gray eyes.
column3: While Thomas Lincoln was living with a farmer and doing odd jobs of carpentering, he met Nancy Hanks, a tall, slender woman, with dark skin, dark brown hair and small, deep set gray eyes.

column2: She had a full forehead, a sharp, angular face and a sad expression.
column3: She had a full forehead, a sharp, angular face and a sad expression.

column2: Yet her disposition was generally cheerful.
column3: Yet her disposition was generally cheerful.

column2: For her backwoods advantages she was considered well educated.
column3: For her backwoods advantages she was considered well educated.

column2: She read well and could write, too.
column3: She read well and could write, too.

column2: It is stated that Nancy Hanks taught Thomas Lincoln to write his own name.
column3: It is stated that Nancy Hanks taught Thomas Lincoln to write his own name.

column2: Thomas was twenty-eight and Nancy twenty-three when their wedding day came. Christopher Columbus Graham, when almost one hundred years old, gave the following description of the marriage feast of the Lincoln bride and groom:
column3: Thomas was twenty eight and Nancy twenty three when their wedding day came. Christopher Columbus Graham, when almost one hundred years old, gave the following description of the marriage feast of the Lincoln bride and groom:

column2: I am one of the two living men who can prove that Abraham Lincoln, or Linkhorn, as the family was miscalled, was born in lawful wedlock, for I saw Thomas Lincoln marry Nancy Hanks on the 12th day of June, 1806.	I am one of the two living men who can prove that Abraham Lincoln, or Linkhorn, as the family was miscalled, was born in lawful wedlock, for I saw Thomas Lincoln marry Nancy Hanks on the twelfth day of June, eighteen o six.
column3: false

column2: I was hunting roots for my medicine and just went to the wedding to get a good supper and got it.
column3: I was hunting roots for my medicine and just went to the wedding to get a good supper and got it.

column2: Tom Lincoln was a carpenter, and a good one for those days, when a cabin was built mainly with the ax, and not a nail or a bolt or hinge in it, only leathers and pins to the doors, and no glass, except in watches and spectacles and bottles.	Tom Lincoln was a carpenter, and a good one for those days, when a cabin was built mainly with the ax, and not a nail or a bolt or hinge in it, only leathers and pins to the doors, and no glass, except in watches and spectacles and bottles.
column3: true

column2: Tom had the best set of tools in what was then and is now Washington County.
column3: Tom had the best set of tools in what was then and is now Washington County.

column2: Jesse Head, the good Methodist minister that married them, was also a carpenter or cabinet maker by trade, and as he was then a neighbor, they were good friends.	Jesse Head, the good Methodist minister that married them, was also a carpenter or cabinet maker by trade, and as he was then a neighbor, they were good friends.
column3: true

column2: While you pin me down to facts, I will say that I saw Nancy Hanks Lincoln at her wedding, a fresh-looking girl, I should say over twenty. Tom was a respectable mechanic and could choose, and she was treated with respect.	While you pin me down to facts, I will say that I saw Nancy Hanks Lincoln at her wedding, a fresh looking girl, I should say over twenty. Tom was a respectable mechanic and could choose, and she was treated with respect.
column3: true

column2: I was at the infare, too, given by John H. Parrott, her guardian, and only girls with money had guardians appointed by the court.	I was at the infare, too, given by john h Parrott, her guardian, and only girls with money had guardians appointed by the court.
column3: true

column2: We had bear meat; venison; wild turkey and ducks' eggs, wild and tame--so common that you could buy them at two bits a bushel; maple sugar, swung on a string, to bite off for coffee; syrup in big gourds, peach and honey; a sheep that the two families barbecued whole over coals of wood burned in a pit, and covered with green boughs to keep the juices in.
column3: We had bear meat; venison; wild turkey and ducks' eggs, wild and tame-so common that you could buy them at two bits a bushel; maple sugar, swung on a string, to bite off for coffee; syrup in big gourds, peach and honey; a sheep that the two families barbecued whole over coals of wood burned in a pit, and covered with green boughs to keep the juices in.

column2: Our table was of the puncheons cut from solid logs, and the next day they were the floor of the new cabin."
column3: Our table was of the puncheons cut from solid logs, and the next day they were the floor of the new cabin."

column2: Thomas Lincoln took his bride to live in a little log cabin in a Kentucky settlement--not a village or hardly a hamlet--called Elizabethtown.
column3: Thomas Lincoln took his bride to live in a little log cabin in a Kentucky settlement-not a village or hardly a hamlet-called Elizabethtown.

column2: He evidently thought this place would be less lonesome for his wife, while he was away hunting and carpentering, than the lonely farm he had purchased in Hardin County, about fourteen miles away.
column3: He evidently thought this place would be less lonesome for his wife, while he was away hunting and carpentering, than the lonely farm he had purchased in Hardin County, about fourteen miles away.

column2: There was so little carpentering or cabinet making to do that he could make a better living by farming or hunting.
column3: There was so little carpentering or cabinet making to do that he could make a better living by farming or hunting.

column2: Thomas was very fond of shooting and as he was a fine marksman he could provide game for the table, and other things which are considered luxuries to-day, such as furs and skins needed for the primitive wearing apparel of the pioneers.
column3: Thomas was very fond of shooting and as he was a fine marksman he could provide game for the table, and other things which are considered luxuries to day, such as furs and skins needed for the primitive wearing apparel of the pioneers.

column2: A daughter was born to the young couple at Elizabethtown, whom they named Sarah.
column3: A daughter was born to the young couple at Elizabethtown, whom they named Sarah.

column2: Dennis Hanks, a cousin of Nancy, lived near the Lincolns in the early days of their married life, and gave Mrs. Eleanor Atkinson this description of their early life together:
column3: Dennis Hanks, a cousin of Nancy, lived near the Lincolns in the early days of their married life, and gave mrs Eleanor Atkinson this description of their early life together:

column2: Looks didn't count them days, nohow.	Looks didn't count them days, nohow.
column3: true

column2: It was stren'th an' work an' daredevil.
column3: It was stren'th an' work an' daredevil.

column2: A lazy man or a coward was jist pizen, an' a spindlin' feller had to stay in the settlemints.
column3: A lazy man or a coward was jist pizen, an' a spindlin' feller had to stay in the settlemints.

column2: The clearin's hadn't no use fur him.
column3: The clearin's hadn't no use fur him.

column2: Tom was strong, an' he wasn't lazy nor afeer'd o' nothin', but he was kind o' shif'less--couldn't git nothin' ahead, an' didn't keer putickalar. Lots o' them kind o' fellers in 'arly days, 'druther hunt and fish, an' I reckon they had their use.
column3: Tom was strong, an' he wasn't lazy nor afeer'd o' nothin', but he was kind o' shif'less-couldn't git nothin' ahead, an' didn't keer putickalar. Lots o' them kind o' fellers in 'arly days, 'druther hunt and fish, an' I reckon they had their use.

column2: They killed off the varmints an' made it safe fur other fellers to go into the woods with an ax.
column3: They killed off the varmints an' made it safe fur other fellers to go into the woods with an ax.

column2: When Nancy married Tom he was workin' in a carpenter shop.	When Nancy married Tom he was workin' in a carpenter shop.
column3: true

column2: It wasn't Tom's fault he couldn't make a livin' by his trade.
column3: It wasn't Tom's fault he couldn't make a livin' by his trade.

column2: Thar was sca'cely any money in that kentry.
column3: Thar was sca'cely any money in that kentry.

column2: Every man had to do his own tinkerin', an' keep everlastin'ly at work to git enough to eat.
column3: Every man had to do his own tinkerin', an' keep everlastin'ly at work to git enough to eat.

column2: So Tom tuk up some land.
column3: So Tom tuk up some land.

column2: It was mighty ornery land, but it was the best Tom could git, when he hadn't much to trade fur it.
column3: It was mighty ornery land, but it was the best Tom could git, when he hadn't much to trade fur it.

column2: Pore?	Pore?
column3: true

column2: We was all pore, them days, but the Lincolns was porer than anybody.
column3: We was all pore, them days, but the Lincolns was porer than anybody.

column2: Choppin' trees an' grubbin' roots an' splittin' rails an' huntin' an' trappin' didn't leave Tom no time.
column3: Choppin' trees an' grubbin' roots an' splittin' rails an' huntin' an' trappin' didn't leave Tom no time.

column2: It was all he could do to git his fambly enough to eat and to kiver 'em.
column3: It was all he could do to git his fambly enough to eat and to kiver 'em.

column2: Nancy was turrible ashamed o' the way they lived, but she knowed Tom was doin' his best, an' she wa'n't the pesterin' kind.
column3: Nancy was turrible ashamed o' the way they lived, but she knowed Tom was doin' his best, an' she wa'n't the pesterin' kind.

column2: She was purty as a pictur' an' smart as you'd find 'em anywhere.
column3: She was purty as a pictur' an' smart as you'd find 'em anywhere.

column2: She could read an' write.
column3: She could read an' write.

column2: The Hankses was some smarter'n the Lincolns.
column3: The Hankses was some smarter'n the Lincolns.

column2: Tom thought a heap o' Nancy, an' he was as good to her as he knowed how.
column3: Tom thought a heap o' Nancy, an' he was as good to her as he knowed how.

column2: He didn't drink or swear or play cyards or fight, an' them was drinkin', cussin', quarrelsome days.
column3: He didn't drink or swear or play cyards or fight, an' them was drinkin', cussin', quarrelsome days.

column2: Tom was popylar, an' he could lick a bully if he had to.
column3: Tom was popylar, an' he could lick a bully if he had to.

column2: He jist couldn't git ahead, somehow."
column3: He jist couldn't git ahead, somehow."

column2: NANCY'S BOY BABY
column3: NANCY'S BOY BABY

column2: Evidently Elizabethtown failed to furnish Thomas Lincoln a living wage from carpentering, for he moved with his young wife and his baby girl to a farm on Nolen Creek, fourteen miles away.
column3: Evidently Elizabethtown failed to furnish Thomas Lincoln a living wage from carpentering, for he moved with his young wife and his baby girl to a farm on Nolen Creek, fourteen miles away.

column2: The chief attraction of the so-called farm was a fine spring of water bubbling up in the shade of a small grove.
column3: The chief attraction of the so-called farm was a fine spring of water bubbling up in the shade of a small grove.

column2: From this spring the place came to be known as "Rock Spring Farm."
column3: From this spring the place came to be known as "Rock Spring Farm."

column2: It was a barren spot and the cabin on it was a rude and primitive sort of home for a carpenter and joiner to occupy.
column3: It was a barren spot and the cabin on it was a rude and primitive sort of home for a carpenter and joiner to occupy.

column2: It contained but a single room, with only one window and one door.
column3: It contained but a single room, with only one window and one door.

column2: There was a wide fireplace in the big chimney which was built outside.
column3: There was a wide fireplace in the big chimney which was built outside.

column2: But that rude hut became the home of "the greatest American."
column3: But that rude hut became the home of "the greatest American."

column2: Abraham Lincoln was born to poverty and privation, but he was never a pauper.
column3: Abraham Lincoln was born to poverty and privation, but he was never a pauper.

column2: His hardships were those of many other pioneers, the wealthiest of whom suffered greater privations than the poorest laboring man has to endure to-day.
column3: His hardships were those of many other pioneers, the wealthiest of whom suffered greater privations than the poorest laboring man has to endure to day.

column2: After his nomination to the presidency, Mr. Lincoln gave to Mr. Hicks, a portrait painter, this memorandum of his birth:
column3: After his nomination to the presidency, mr Lincoln gave to mr Hicks, a portrait painter, this memorandum of his birth:

column2: I was born February 12, 1809, in then Hardin County, Kentucky, at a point within the now county of Larue, a mile or a mile and a half from where Hodgen's mill now is.	I was born february twelfth eighteen o nine, in then Hardin county kentucky, at a point within the now county of Larue, a mile or a mile and a half from where Hodgen's mill now is.
column3: true

column2: My parents being dead, and my memory not serving, I know no means of identifying the precise locality. It was on Nolen Creek.
column3: My parents being dead, and my memory not serving, I know no means of identifying the precise locality. It was on Nolen Creek.

column2: A.	A.
column3: false

column2: LINCOLN. "JUNE 14, 1860."
column3: LINCOLN. "june fourteenth eighteen sixty."

column2: The exact spot was identified after his death, and the house was found standing many years later.
column3: The exact spot was identified after his death, and the house was found standing many years later.

column2: The logs were removed to Chicago, for the World's Columbian Exposition, in 1893, and the cabin was reconstructed and exhibited there and elsewhere in the United States.
column3: The logs were removed to Chicago, for the World's Columbian Exposition, in eighteen ninety three, and the cabin was reconstructed and exhibited there and elsewhere in the United States.

column2: The materials were taken back to their original site, and a fine marble structure now encloses the precious relics of the birthplace of "the first American," as Lowell calls Lincoln in his great "Commemoration Ode."
column3: The materials were taken back to their original site, and a fine marble structure now encloses the precious relics of the birthplace of "the first American," as Lowell calls Lincoln in his great "Commemoration Ode."

column2: Cousin Dennis Hanks gives the following quaint description of "Nancy's boy baby," as reported by Mrs. Eleanor Atkinson in her little book on "Lincoln's Boyhood."
column3: Cousin Dennis Hanks gives the following quaint description of "Nancy's boy baby," as reported by mrs Eleanor Atkinson in her little book on "Lincoln's Boyhood."

column2: Tom an' Nancy lived on a farm about two miles from us, when Abe was born.	Tom an' Nancy lived on a farm about two miles from us, when Abe was born.
column3: false

column2: I ricollect Tom comin' over to our house one cold mornin' in Feb'uary an' sayin' kind o' slow, 'Nancy's got a boy baby.'
column3: I ricollect Tom comin' over to our house one cold mornin' in Feb'uary an' sayin' kind o' slow, 'Nancy's got a boy baby.'

column2: Mother got flustered an' hurried up 'er work to go over to look after the little feller, but I didn't have nothin' to wait fur, so I cut an' run the hull two mile to see my new cousin.	Mother got flustered an' hurried up 'er work to go over to look after the little feller, but I didn't have nothin' to wait fur, so I cut an' run the hull two mile to see my new cousin.
column3: false

column2: You bet I was tickled to death.	You bet I was tickled to death.
column3: true

column2: Babies wasn't as common as blackberries in the woods o' Kaintucky.
column3: Babies wasn't as common as blackberries in the woods o' Kaintucky.

column2: Mother come over an' washed him an' put a yaller flannel petticoat on him, an' cooked some dried berries with wild honey fur Nancy, an' slicked things up an' went home.
column3: Mother come over an' washed him an' put a yaller flannel petticoat on him, an' cooked some dried berries with wild honey fur Nancy, an' slicked things up an' went home.

column2: An' that's all the nuss'n either of 'em got.
column3: An' that's all the nuss'n either of 'em got.

column2: I rolled up in a b'ar skin an' slep' by the fireplace that night, so's I could see the little feller when he cried an' Tom had to get up an' tend to him.	I rolled up in a b'ar skin an' slep' by the fireplace that night, so's I could see the little feller when he cried an' Tom had to get up an' tend to him.
column3: false

column2: Nancy let me hold him purty soon.
column3: Nancy let me hold him purty soon.

column2: Folks often ask me if Abe was a good lookin' baby.
column3: Folks often ask me if Abe was a good lookin' baby.

column2: Well, now, he looked just like any other baby, at fust--like red cherry pulp squeezed dry.
column3: Well, now, he looked just like any other baby, at fust-like red cherry pulp squeezed dry.

column2: An' he didn't improve none as he growed older.
column3: An' he didn't improve none as he growed older.

column2: Abe never was much fur looks.
column3: Abe never was much fur looks.

column2: I ricollect how Tom joked about Abe's long legs when he was toddlin' round the cabin.
column3: I ricollect how Tom joked about Abe's long legs when he was toddlin' round the cabin.

column2: He growed out o' his clothes faster'n Nancy could make 'em.
column3: He growed out o' his clothes faster'n Nancy could make 'em.

column2: But he was mighty good comp'ny, solemn as a papoose, but interested in everything.	But he was mighty good comp'ny, solemn as a papoose, but interested in everything.
column3: true

column2: An' he always did have fits o' cuttin' up.
column3: An' he always did have fits o' cuttin' up.

column2: I've seen him when he was a little feller, settin' on a stool, starin' at a visitor. All of a sudden he'd bu'st out laughin' fit to kill.
column3: I've seen him when he was a little feller, settin' on a stool, starin' at a visitor. All of a sudden he'd bu'st out laughin' fit to kill.

column2: If he told us what he was laughin' at, half the time we couldn't see no joke.
column3: If he told us what he was laughin' at, half the time we couldn't see no joke.

column2: Abe never give Nancy no trouble after he could walk excep' to keep him in clothes.	Abe never give Nancy no trouble after he could walk excep' to keep him in clothes.
column3: true

column2: Most o' the time he went bar'foot.
column3: Most o' the time he went bar'foot.

column2: Ever wear a wet buckskin glove?
column3: Ever wear a wet buckskin glove?

column2: Them moccasins wasn't no putection ag'inst the wet.
column3: Them moccasins wasn't no putection ag'inst the wet.

column2: Birch bark with hickory bark soles, strapped on over yarn socks, beat buckskin all holler, fur snow.
column3: Birch bark with hickory bark soles, strapped on over yarn socks, beat buckskin all holler, fur snow.

column2: Abe'n me got purty handy contrivin' things that way. An' Abe was right out in the woods about as soon's he was weaned, fishin' in the creek, settin' traps fur rabbits an' muskrats, goin' on coon-hunts with Tom an' me an' the dogs, follerin' up bees to find bee-trees, an' drappin' corn fur his pappy.
column3: Abe'n me got purty handy contrivin' things that way. An' Abe was right out in the woods about as soon's he was weaned, fishin' in the creek, settin' traps fur rabbits an' muskrats, goin' on coon hunts with Tom an' me an' the dogs, follerin' up bees to find bee trees, an' drappin' corn fur his pappy.

column2: Mighty interestin' life fur a boy, but thar was a good many chances he wouldn't live to grow up."
column3: Mighty interestin' life fur a boy, but thar was a good many chances he wouldn't live to grow up."

column2: When little Abe was four years old his father and mother moved from Rock Spring Farm to a better place on Knob Creek, a few miles to the northeast of the farm where he was born.
column3: When little Abe was four years old his father and mother moved from Rock Spring Farm to a better place on Knob Creek, a few miles to the northeast of the farm where he was born.

column2: CHAPTER III
column3: CHAPTER three

column2: THE BOY LINCOLN'S BEST TEACHER
column3: THE BOY LINCOLN'S BEST TEACHER

column2: At Knob Creek the boy began to go to an "A B C" school.
column3: At Knob Creek the boy began to go to an "A B C" school.

column2: His first teacher was Zachariah Riney.
column3: His first teacher was Zachariah Riney.

column2: Of course, there were no regular schools in the backwoods then.
column3: Of course, there were no regular schools in the backwoods then.

column2: When a man who "knew enough" happened to come along, especially if he had nothing else to do, he tried to teach the children of the pioneers in a poor log schoolhouse.
column3: When a man who "knew enough" happened to come along, especially if he had nothing else to do, he tried to teach the children of the pioneers in a poor log schoolhouse.

column2: It is not likely that little Abe went to school more than a few weeks at this time, for he never had a year's schooling in his life.
column3: It is not likely that little Abe went to school more than a few weeks at this time, for he never had a year's schooling in his life.

column2: There was another teacher afterward at Knob Creek--a man named Caleb Hazel.
column3: There was another teacher afterward at Knob Creek-a man named Caleb Hazel.

column2: Little is known of either of these teachers except that he taught little Abe Lincoln.
column3: Little is known of either of these teachers except that he taught little Abe Lincoln.

column2: If their pupil had not become famous the men and their schools would never have been mentioned in history.
column3: If their pupil had not become famous the men and their schools would never have been mentioned in history.
